captions.text:
To many, one of the coolest things
about "Game of Thrones"

is that the inhabitants
of the Dothraki Sea
have their own real language.
And Dothraki came hot on the heels

of the real language
that the Na'vi speak in "Avatar,"
which, surely, the Na'vi needed

when the Klingons in "Star Trek" have had
their own whole language since 1979.
And let's not forget the Elvish languages

in J.R.R. Tolkien's
"Lord of the Rings" trilogy,

especially since that was
the official grandfather
of the fantasy conlangs.

"Conlang" is short for
"constructed language."
They're more than codes like Pig Latin,

and they're not just collections
of fabricated slang like the Nadsat lingo

that the teen hoodlums
in "A Clockwork Orange" speak,

where "droog" from Russian
happens to mean "friend."

What makes conlangs real languages
isn't the number of words they have.

It helps, of course,
to have a lot of words.
Dothraki has thousands of words.
Na'vi started with 1,500 words.

Fans on websites
have steadily created more.

But we can see the difference
between vocabulary alone
and what makes a real language

from a look at how Tolkien
put together grand old Elvish,
a conlang with several thousands words.

After all, you could memorize
5,000 words of Russian

and still be barely able
to construct a sentence.

A four-year-old would talk
rings around you.

That's because you have to know
how to put the words together.
That is, a real language has grammar.
Elvish does.

In English, to make a verb past,
you add an "-ed."
Wash, washed.
In Elvish, "wash" is "allu"
and "washed" is "allune."
Real languages also change over time.
There's no such thing as a language

that's the same today
as it was a thousand years ago.

As people speak, they drift
into new habits,
shed old ones,
make mistakes, and get creative.
Today, one says,
"Give us today our daily bread."
In Old English, they said,

"Urne gedaeghwamlican
hlaf syle us todaeg."
Things change in conlangs, too.

Tolkien charted out ancient
and newer versions of Elvish.
When the first Elves awoke at Cuiviénen,
in their new language,
the word for "people" was "kwendi,"

but in the language of one of the groups
that moved away, Teleri,
over time, "kwendi" became "pendi,"
with the "k" turning into a "p."

And just like real languages,
conlangs like Elvish split off into many.

When the Romans transplanted
Latin across Europe,
French, Spanish, and Italian were born.
When groups move to different places,

over time, their ways
of speaking grow apart,
just like everything else about them.
Thus, Latin's word for hand was "manus,"
but in French, it became "main,"
while in Spain it became "mano."

Tolkien made sure Elvish
did the same kind of thing.

While that original word
"kwendi" became "pendi"
among the Teleri,

among the Avari, who spread
throughout Middle Earth,

it became "kindi"
when the "w" dropped out.

The Elvish varieties Tolkien
fleshed out the most
are Quenya and Sindarin,

and their words are different
in the same way French and Spanish are.
Quenya has "suc" for "drink,"
Sindarin has "sog."
And as you know, real languages are messy.
That's because they change,

and change has a way
of working against order,

just like in a living room
or on a bookshelf.

Real languages are never
perfectly logical.

That's why Tolkien made sure
that Elvish had plenty of exceptions.

Lots of verbs are conjugated
in ways you just have to know.
Take even the word "know."
In the past, it's "knew,"

which isn't explained
by any of the rules in English.
Oh well.
In Elvish, "know" is "ista,"
but "knew" is "sinte."
Oh well.

The truth is, though, that Elvish
is more a sketch for a real language
than a whole one.
For Tolkien, Elvish was a hobby

rather than an attempt to create something
people could actually speak.

Much of the Elvish the characters
in the "Lord of the Rings" movies speak

has been made up since Tolkien
by dedicated fans of Elvish

based on guesses as to what Tolkien
would have constructed.

That's the best we can do for Elvish
because there are no actual Elves around
to speak it for us.
But the modern conlangs go further.

Dothraki, Na'vi, and Klingon
are developed enough
that you can actually speak them.

Here's a translation
of "Hamlet" into Klingon,

although performing it
would mean getting used
to pronouncing "k" with your uvula,

that weird, cartoony thing hanging
in the back of your throat.

Believe it or not, you actually do that
in plenty of languages around the world,
like Eskimo ones.
Pronouncing Elvish is much easier, though.
So, let's take our leave for now

from this introduction
to conlangs in Elvish
and the other three conlangs discussed

with a heartfelt
quad-conlangual valedictory:
"A Na Marie!"
"Hajas!"
Na'vi's "Kiyevame!"
"Qapla!"
and "Goodbye!"

title: Are Elvish, Klingon, Dothraki and Na'vi real languages? - John McWhorter

comments.text:
Interesting point: the counter-intuitional changing of kw- into p- in some 
Elvish dialects is historical fact; Tolkien must have taken this 
development from the Celtic languages, which are still divided into 
P-Celtic (Welsh, Breton, Cornish) and Q-Celtic (Gaelic, Irish, Manx). (I 
know nothing about Tolkien, but I'm up on my British linguistics.)﻿
comments.author: RobMacKendrick

comments.text:
+RobMacKendrick Quenya is inspired by Welsh, while Sindarin is inspired by 
Finnish.

To say J.R. Tolkien's languages were just a hobby is almost insulting to

Hti xyekc dnamr gaq pywjib alin hti vosu baf.﻿

comments.text:
Come to think of it, english language speakers live in countries far away 
from each other that if there was something to severe the bond that ties 
them together(e.g. the loss of its position as the dominant second 
language), the dialects they spoke will diverge much more, than for 
example, spanish in the americas, whose native speakers live much closer to 
each other where mutual influence is sustained due to geographical 
proximity.﻿

comments.author: Anny Windlord

comments.text:
Here is interestingly exempt from Wikipedia on the Khuzdul language, 
how the Dwarves prevent change in their language:-

'It is said in The Silmarillion that Aulë, the creator of the first 
Dwarves, taught them "the language he had devised for them," which implies 
that Khuzdul is technically, in reality and fictionally, a constructed 
language. It is also said that because of the Dwarves' great reverence for 
Aulë their language remained unchanged, and all clans could still speak 
with each other without difficulty despite the great distances that 
separated them. Due to their reverence for their cultural heritage, the 
Dwarves did not learn Khuzdul as a cradle-speech, as this might mutate the 
language over time. Instead, Dwarves carefully learned Khuzdul through 
reverent study as they matured, to make sure that their language was passed 
down unaltered from one generation to the next. The changeability of 
Khuzdul versus other languages was compared to "the weathering of hard rock 
and the melting of snow".'   -sourcehttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khuzdul﻿
comments.author: IonTorch52

comments.author: Fabio Beka

comments.text:
So he took Elvish 'Kwendi' and turned it into 'Pendi'? Seems exactly like 
the Celtic language split. I admire Tolkien, but that's incredibly 
uninteresting. One should always take into 
account Assimilation, Dissimulation, Metathesis, Haplology, and other 
phænomenon when creating a language, or even simply studying historical 
linguistics. Make it interesting; natural languages ALWAYS have something 
interesting about them, even if they're not technical or complex.﻿
comments.author: NovembreLaMorte

comments.text: +NovembreLaMorte Meh. I'm still a cool cup.
comments.author: MrCool Cup

comments.text:
+MrCool Cup I know my facts and I know of Tokien's work and studies and 
education. Historical Linguistics is my specialty as well, and I understand 
the phonetic conditions which cause the kw/p change. I just think it's 
uninteresting to repeat such a change, especially in a language which was 
largely modelled after Welsh (and Finnish). And I wouldn't comment before 
knowing my facts. You shouldn't judge without getting to know someone. It 
makes you sound pretentious. (Also, the video says that the know/knew 
conversion isn't explainable. But clearly the Germanic Strong Verb explains 
it).
comments.author: NovembreLaMorte

comments.text: Know your facts before you say something.
comments.author: MrCool Cup

comments.text:
He had studied historical linguistics, in fact he was a professor of old 
English in addition to knowing Latin. But I do see your point.

comments.text:
+Jonathan Harding Actually, just like the elvish, a structure is being made 
by fans over the internet and it's becoming quite complex. Though is 
relatively easy to learn since even from the beginning it had an 
english-like structure. Conjugations are being created, exceptions and even

comments.author: Ch1Frequency

comments.text:
If I recall, in an interview the man who made up the dragon language used 
in Skyrim said he took all the words in your average English dictionary and 
created translations for them. But in the game, the language is practically 
dead, no one outside of the Greybeards speaks it, so the Dovakhiin would 
have no reason to learn it unless he were to spend the rest of his days as 
a Greybeard. That's why they never created a structure for the language, 
because you never use it outside of a Shout.
So in my opinion, it is a language, there is just no structure that allows 
you to use it in everyday communication.
But I'll be damned if I can't use it (as a language) in a normal 
conversation!

Although it would be cool if they had created a structure for it and that 
you could actually learn it.
comments.author: Jonathan “Cannibal Predator” Harding

comments.text:
Christ - aren't there enough already-natural languages on earth to memorize 
& keep alive?
Do we need to create FANTASY languages, too?

I've done the whole "learn a 2nd (& 3rd & 4th) language" thing in my life.
Never got any practical use out of it.
I will stick to my native English & work on computers to translate.﻿
comments.author: IThinkWithMy Liver

comments.text:
Maybe not in a strictly regimental efficiency model of the world but  
Language is a valuable resource and their existence actually prevents a lot 
of civil unrest.

Obviously, more than 1 natural language exist, because humans, like all

+NovembreLaMorte "You need to learn that your perspectives are erroneous"

You said that, but previously contradicted yourself by stating that English 
basically acts as a linguistic-social-equalizer in India (roughly).  I am 
not saying you are wrong about the latter. But, I do demand logical 
consistency, which is the same in ANY language!

I spent 9 weeks in the Soviet Union.
Only proved to me we need more work on computer translators.

"the fact that we haven't all been replaced with these translators says 
something."

You're right. It does. We need more work on computer translators.
comments.author: IThinkWithMy Liver

comments.text:
+Grokford "It is useful in providing factors that don't  occur naturally in 
living languages or even to help resurrect dead ones. "

I am very glad you brought up that point.
I have high hopes that computer translators can help resurrect dead human 
languages.
comments.author: IThinkWithMy Liver

comments.text:
+IThinkWithMy Liver    Well you may think that but the fact that we haven't 
all been replaced with these translators says something.
As for the artificial languages I recently watched an excellent episode of 
an Indian Broadcast that revolved around a similar issue. There are 
twenty-two languages in India and they were arguing back in forth about the 
relative benefits of Hindi and English. One argument that I found myself 
agreeing with is that English, While not being Indian, provides a basic and 
equally advantageous link language for all Indian People while they can 
maintain their own local languages rather than one gaining dominance as 
Hindi may be doing. That's what many constructed languages are made for, 
but they are also made as a form of artistic expression or merely to test 
hypotheses about how languages and the human mind works. It is useful in 
providing factors that don't  occur naturally in living languages or even 
to help resurrect dead ones. I wasn't propping up Constructed 
languages before but I am now. It is a useful and perfectly human pursuit I 
don't think they should come at the expense of other languages but I don't 
think they do.
comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
+IThinkWithMy Liver Artificial Translators cannot understand some basic 
linguistic circumstances. The most crucial of which is probably context, 
which many languages rely heavily on. For instance, if I say something like 
'merde' to someone about to go on stage, your translator would think I'm 
being a rude Frenchman. But the performer would know exactly what I mean. 
Also, English is one of the most well known languages on Earth, you're 
definitely not being bothered with other languages existing. There are 
probably thousands of actively spoken languages which you've never even 
heard of, and you would therefore not have to 'deal with them'. If you 
learned four languages and found them useless, you're probably useless. You 
obviously never travelled to a country which doesn't actively speak English 
and therefore never had to speak to anyone who doesn't speak English. You 
need to learn that your perspectives are erroneous.
comments.author: NovembreLaMorte

comments.text:
+Grokford Wrong. You need to learn that everybody has different 
perspectives from your own.  And it is unimaginably hypocritical (i.e. 
stupid) to call artificial translators "practically useless" while praising 
yet another artificially constructed language, as if there were not already 
tons of languages on earth to deal with.
comments.author: IThinkWithMy Liver

comments.text:
You must be joking. No human being can learn two languages, let alone four, 
without realizing the practical uselessness of artificial translators.
Besides that though constructed languages are a breed all their own and 
they, while less of a concern than natural languages in most cases, should 
not be ignored.
comments.author: Grokford

+Rúben Luso I studied Spanish for three years before I could have a simple

same in Esperanto. If you know the basics of Esperanto and enough

comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
I don't belive that esperanto have so many speakers by second language.
The majority probably only know the basics and aren't fluent...
comments.author: Rúben Luso

comments.text:
+Rebecca98463 Actually, Esperanto does have native speakers. They're called 
denaskoj in Esperanto. They're usually the offspring of two people who have 
no shared language other than Esperanto and thus usr the language at home, 
imparting it to their children. There are an estimated 1'000 denaskoj, 
including second and third generation native speakers. That's not many, but 
it's more than some endangered languages. So, as far as native speakers 
goes, Esperanto would be an endangered language. But add ~2'000'000 second 
language speakers of Esperanto and it becomes clear that this language 
isn't going anywhere any time soon.
comments.author: Alexander “Zan” King

comments.text:
+Rebecca98463  Factually a languages reality is not defined by its use 
languages don't cease to exist once they have no native speakers. If they 
are not spoken at all they are dead true but secondary languages are no 
less alive simply because they aren't mother-tongues there is a language in 
Peru which is exclusively spoken by medicine men and these men don't begin 
learning it until they are well into their teens. Yet the language lives 
on. We should not be so quick to judge a language based on our own. 
Incidentally however there are native Esperanto speakers I even read about 
a family which has been speaking the language natively for three 
generations.
comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
It wouldn't surprise me, English seems to have changed more than most major 
Languages in the past five centuries.
comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
+Grokford Yes, but I would argue that even less change occurred in 
Icelandic. Although, it could be said that Middle English and Modern 
English's changes were mainly Orthographic because there wasn't really a 
standard of spelling.
comments.author: NovembreLaMorte

comments.text: Similarly to Modern and Middle English then.
comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
Speakers of Iceland can read about 70 per cent of Old Norse without much 
effort. The obvious changes are in words like ON 'ulfr' changing into 
Islandic 'ulfur'. So if you understand these minor changes, you go about 
reading a lot of old texts. People familiar with Old Norse can also 
understand some Norwegian and Swedish too, especially when written. But 
there with be some issues in comprehension when hearing it spoken, because 
of phonetic changes.
comments.author: NovembreLaMorte

comments.text:
+Murdo All languages change over time the only difference is the degree of 
the change. Francophones can read six hundred year-old texts while that 
would be much more difficult for Anglophones.
comments.author: Grokford

comments.text:
+Mathieu Boumal The population of Ireland stood at 8 million before the 
famine of the mid-19th century. 30% were Irish-speakers. The English 
language was acquired and the Irish language lost at different times in 
different places. Over time, the Irish-speakers became cut off from one 
another and the dialects, that had already been in existence, further 
diverged from one another. Add to that English-speaking Anglo-Irish in the 
east and midlands and English-speaking and Scots-speaking Scottish settlers 
in the north of Ireland and you have much linguistic diversity.
comments.author: Caer Kajab

comments.text:
Since Iceland is so cut off from the rest of the world (and especially was 
before the internet and things of that sort, I suppose), it didn't really 
get into contact with any other languages, which is I guess a huge factor 
in the evolution of a language. Plus, there's always been very few people 
in Iceland. Even today the population is like 300,000 if I'm not mistaken 
and most of it is contained in one city. Imagine what the number was a 
hundered years ago. And from what I've read, Icelanders weren't cut off 
from each other at all and have always been able to easily travel between 
other parts of the country, which helps in the natural "unification" of a 
language since different groups of people still communicate with each other.
It's funny to think of it when you know that Ireland is a smaller country 
and yet has lots of different accents depending on where you go. Then again 
maybe Iceland has many accents too but I assume that if the language 
doesn't change, accents don't really do either. I don't know though. I've 
witnessed Irish diversity but I couldn't tell when it comes to Iceland. I'm 
going there next summer but I doubt I'll understand Icelandic by then :p
comments.author: Mathieu Boumal

comments.text: +evilmick66 Good to know. Thank you :)
comments.author: Murdo

comments.text:
Icelandic: Faðir vor, þú sem er á himnum.Helgist þitt nafn, til komi þitt 
ríki, verði þinn vilji svo á jörðu sem á himni.
Old Norse (it's ancestor): Faþer vár es ert í himenríki, verði nafn þitt 
hæilagt til kome ríke þitt, værði vili þin sva a iarðu sem í himnum.

Very little difference, and it is the most conservative of the Scandinavian 
languages, but there is still change. It's almost like the difference 
between modern English and the English written by Chaucer.
